title: Towards MPGDs with embedded pixel ASICs
authors:
L. Scharenberg (1), J. Alozy (1), W. Billereau (1), F. Brunbauer (1),
  M. Campbell (1), P. Carbonez (1), K. J. Fl\"othner (1,2), F. Garcia (3), A.
  Garcia-Tejedor (1,4), T. Genetay (1,4), K. Heijhoff (5), D. Janssens (1), S.
  Kaufmann (1), M. Lisowska (1), X. Llopart (1), M. Mager (1), B. Mehl (1), H.
  Muller (6,1), R. de Oliveira (1), E. Oliveri (1), G. Orlandini (1,7), D.
  Pfeiffer (8,1), F. Piernas Diaz (1), A. Rodrigues (1), L. Ropelewski (1), J.
  Samarati (8), M. van Beuzekom (5), M. Van Stenis (1), R. Veenhof (1), M.
  Vicente (9) ((1) CERN, (2) Helmholtz-Institut f\"ur Strahlen- und Kernphysik,
  University of Bonn, (3) Helsinki Institute of Physics, (4) Institute of
  Radiation Physics, Centre hospitalier universitaire vaudois (CHUV), (5)
  Nikhef (6) Physikalisches Institut, University of Bonn, (7)
  Friedrich-Alexander-Universit\"at Erlangen-N\"urnberg, (8) ESS, (9)
  D\'epartement de physique nucl\'eaire et corpusculaire, University of Geneva)
abstract:
Combining gaseous detectors with a high-granularity pixelated charge readout
enables experimental applications which otherwise could not be achieved. This
includes high-resolution tracking of low-energetic particles, requiring
ultra-low material budget, X-ray polarimetry at low energies ($\lessapprox$ 2
keV) or rare-event searches which profit from event selection based on
geometrical parameters. In this article, the idea of embedding a pixel ASIC -
specifically the Timepix4 - into a micro-pattern gaseous amplification stage is
illustrated. Furthermore, the first results of reading out a triple-GEM
detector with the Timepix4 (GEMPix4) are shown, including the first X-ray
images taken with a Timepix4 utilising Through Silicon Vias (TSVs). Lastly, a
new readout concept is presented, called the 'Silicon Readout Board', extending
the use of pixel ASICs to read out gaseous detectors to a wider range of HEP
applications.
